Available on the web (whatever format), but with an open license  Available as machine-readable structured data (e.g., excel instead of an image scan)  As before, but using a non-proprietary format (e.g., CSV instead of excel)  All the above, plus use open standards (RDF & Co.) to identify things, so that people could point at your stuff  All the above, plus link your data to other people’s data  to provide context  http://dbpedia.org/resource/Available_on_the_web_(whatever_format),_but_with_an_open_license__Available_as_machine-readable_structured_data_(e.g.,_excel_instead_of_an_image_scan)__As_before,_but_using_a_non-proprietary_format_(e.g.,_CSV_instead_of_excel)__All_the_above,_plus_use_open_standards_(RDF_&_Co.)_to_identify_things,_so_that_people_could_point_at_your_stuff__All_the_above,_plus_link_your_data_to_other_people’s_data__to_provide_context_ courses/COMP6721/LEC/LS09.pdf LEC-LS09

 197  } In practice, more complex queries into the RDF data are necessary
§ something like: “give me the (a,b) pair of resources, for which there is an x such that (x parent a) and (b brother x) holds” (ie, return the uncles)
• these rules may become quite complex
} The goal of SPARQL (Query Language for RDF)
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_197__} In_practice,_more_complex_queries_into_the_RDF_data_are_necessary
§ something_like:_“give_me_the_(a,b)_pair_of_resources,_for_which_there_is_an_x_such_that_(x_parent_a)_and_(b_brother_x)_holds”_(ie,_return_the_uncles)
• these_rules_may_become_quite_complex
} The_goal_of_SPARQL_(Query_Language_for_RDF)

59 /779.60 http://dbpedia.org/resource/59_/779.60 courses/COMP6721/LEC/LS09.pdf LEC-LS09
(199)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(199)_ courses/COMP6721/LEC/LS09.pdf LEC-LS09
 199  } The fundamental idea: use graph patterns
§ the pattern contains unbound symbols
§ by binding the symbols, subgraphs of the RDF graph are selected
§ if there is such a selection, the query returns the bound resources
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_199__} The_fundamental_idea:_use_graph_patterns
§ the_pattern_contains_unbound_symbols
§ by_binding_the_symbols,_subgraphs_of_the_RDF_graph_are_selected
§ if_there_is_such_a_selection,_the_query_returns_the_bound_resources

 64  } For example, using Python+RDFLib:
§ a “Graph” object is created
§ the RDF ﬁle is parsed and results stored in the Graph
§ the Graph offers methods to retrieve (or add):
• triples
• (property,object) pairs for a speciﬁc subject
• (subject,property) pairs for speciﬁc object
• etc.
§ the rest is conventional programming…
} Similar tools exist in Java, PHP , etc.
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_64__} For_example,_using_Python+RDFLib:
§ a_“Graph”_object_is_created
§ the_RDF_ﬁle_is_parsed_and_results_stored_in_the_Graph
§ the_Graph_offers_methods_to_retrieve_(or_add):
• triples
• (property,object)_pairs_for_a_speciﬁc_subject
• (subject,property)_pairs_for_speciﬁc_object
• etc.
§ the_rest_is_conventional_programming…
} Similar_tools_exist_in_Java,_PHP_,_etc.

  # create a graph from a file   graph = rdflib.Graph()   graph.parse("filename.rdf", format="rdfxml")   # take subject with a known URI   subject = rdflib.URIRef("URI_of_Subject")   # process all properties and objects for this subject   for (s,p,o) in graph.triples((subject,None,None)) :     do_something(p,o)     http://dbpedia.org/resource/__#_create_a_graph_from_a_file___graph_=_rdflib.Graph()___graph.parse("filename.rdf",_format="rdfxml")___#_take_subject_with_a_known_URI___subject_=_rdflib.URIRef("URI_of_Subject")___#_process_all_properties_and_objects_for_this_subject___for_(s,p,o)_in_graph.triples((subject,None,None))_:_____do_something(p,o)____ courses/COMP6721/LEC/LS08.pdf LEC-LS08

 30  } User of data “F” can now ask queries like:
§ “give me the title of the original”
• well, … « donnes-moi le titre de l’original »
} This information is not in the dataset “F”…
} …but can be retrieved by merging with dataset “A”!
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_30__} User_of_data_“F”_can_now_ask_queries_like:
§ “give_me_the_title_of_the_original”

(31)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(31)_ courses/COMP6721/LEC/LS08.pdf LEC-LS08
 31  } We “feel” that a:author and f:auteur should be the same
} But an automatic merge doest not know that!
} Let us add some extra information to the merged data:
§ a:author same as f:auteur
§ both identify a “Person”
§ a term that a community may have already deﬁned:
• a “Person” is uniquely identiﬁed by his/her name and, say, homepage
• it can be used as a “category” for certain type of resources
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_31__} We_“feel”_that_a:author_and_f:auteur_should_be_the_same
} But_an_automatic_merge_doest_not_know_that!
} Let_us_add_some_extra_information_to_the_merged_data:
§ a:author_same_as_f:auteur
§ both_identify_a_“Person”
§ a_term_that_a_community_may_have_already_deﬁned:
• a_“Person”_is_uniquely_identiﬁed_by_his/her_name_and,_say,_homepage
• it_can_be_used_as_a_“category”_for_certain_type_of_resources

 33  } User of dataset “F” can now query:
§ “donnes-moi la page d’accueil de l’auteur de l’original”
• well… “give me the home page of the original’s ‘auteur’”
} The information is not in datasets “F” or “A”…
} …but was made available by:
§ merging datasets “A” and datasets “F”
§ adding three simple extra statements as an extra “glue”
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_33__} User_of_dataset_“F”_can_now_query:
§ “donnes-moi_la_page_d’accueil_de_l’auteur_de_l’original”
• well…_“give_me_the_home_page_of_the_original’s_‘auteur’”
} The_information_is_not_in_datasets_“F”_or_“A”…
} …but_was_made_available_by:
§ merging_datasets_“A”_and_datasets_“F”

 223  } Data integration needs agreements on
§ terms 
• “translator”, “author”
§ categories used 
• “Person”, “literature”
§ relationships among those 
• “an author is also a Person…”, “historical ﬁction is a narrower term than ﬁction”
• ie, new relationships can be deduced

 224  } There is a need for “languages” to deﬁne such vocabularies
§ to deﬁne those vocabularies
§ to assign clear “semantics” on how new relationships can be deduced

(69)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(69)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS04.pdf LEC-LS04
 69  } Think of well known traditional vocabularies:
§ use the term “novel”
§ “every novel is a ﬁction”
§ “«The Glass Palace» is a novel”
§ etc.
} RDFS deﬁnes resources and classes:
§ everything in RDF is a “resource”
§ “classes” are also resources, but…
§ …they are also a collection of possible resources (i.e., “individuals”)
• “ﬁction”, “novel”, …
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_69__} Think_of_well_known_traditional_vocabularies:
§ use_the_term_“novel”
§ “every_novel_is_a_ﬁction”
§ “«The_Glass_Palace»_is_a_novel”
§ etc.
} RDFS_deﬁnes_resources_and_classes:
§ everything_in_RDF_is_a_“resource”
§ “classes”_are_also_resources,_but…
§ …they_are_also_a_collection_of_possible_resources_(i.e.,_“individuals”)
• “ﬁction”,_“novel”,_…

(70)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(70)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS04.pdf LEC-LS04
 70  } Relationships are deﬁned among resources:
§ “typing”: an individual belongs to a speciﬁc class 
• “«The Glass Palace» is a novel”
• to be more precise: “«http://.../000651409X» is a novel”
§ “subclassing”: all instances of one are also the instances of the other (“every novel is a ﬁction”)
} RDFS formalizes these notions in RDF
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_70__} Relationships_are_deﬁned_among_resources:
§ “typing”:_an_individual_belongs_to_a_speciﬁc_class_
• “«The_Glass_Palace»_is_a_novel”
• to_be_more_precise:_“«http://.../000651409X»_is_a_novel”
§ “subclassing”:_all_instances_of_one_are_also_the_instances_of_the_other_(“every_novel_is_a_ﬁction”)
} RDFS_formalizes_these_notions_in_RDF

 307  } eClassOwl: eBusiness ontology for products and services, 75,000 classes and 5,500 properties

 197  } In practice, more complex queries into the RDF data are necessary
§ something like: “give me the (a,b) pair of resources, for which there is an x such that (x parent a) and (b brother x) holds” (ie, return the uncles)
• these rules may become quite complex
} The goal of SPARQL (Query Language for RDF)
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_197__} In_practice,_more_complex_queries_into_the_RDF_data_are_necessary

 199  } The fundamental idea: use graph patterns
§ the pattern contains unbound symbols
§ by binding the symbols, subgraphs of the RDF graph are selected
§ if there is such a selection, the query returns the bound resources
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_199__} The_fundamental_idea:_use_graph_patterns
§ the_pattern_contains_unbound_symbols
§ by_binding_the_symbols,_subgraphs_of_the_RDF_graph_are_selected
§ if_there_is_such_a_selection,_the_query_returns_the_bound_resources

 211  } Limit the number of returned results; remove duplicates, sort them, …
} Specify several data sources (via URI-s) within the query
} Construct a graph combining a separate pattern and the query results
} Use datatypes and/or language tags when matching a pattern
} Aggregation of the results (min, max, average, etc.)
} Path expressions (a bit like regular expressions)

 212  } SPARQL is usually used over the network

§ result is the result of the SELECT, the CONSTRUCT,…

• SPARQL Protocol for RDF with HTTP and SOAP bindings
• SPARQL results in XML or JSON formats

(171)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(171)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS04.pdf LEC-LS04
 171  } Goal: “expose” datasets on the Web
§ remember the importance of data!
} Set links among the data items from different datasets
§ we want to avoid the silo effects
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_171__} Goal:_“expose”_datasets_on_the_Web
§ remember_the_importance_of_data!

 172   http://dbpedia.org/resource/_172__ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS04.pdf LEC-LS04
Available on the web (whatever format), but with an open license  Available as machine-readable structured data (e.g., excel instead of an image scan)  As before, but using a non-proprietary format (e.g., CSV instead of excel)  All the above, plus use open standards (RDF & Co.) to identify things, so that people could point at your stuff  All the above, plus link your data to other people’s data  to provide context  http://dbpedia.org/resource/Available_on_the_web_(whatever_format),_but_with_an_open_license__Available_as_machine-readable_structured_data_(e.g.,_excel_instead_of_an_image_scan)__As_before,_but_using_a_non-proprietary_format_(e.g.,_CSV_instead_of_excel)__All_the_above,_plus_use_open_standards_(RDF_&_Co.)_to_identify_things,_so_that_people_could_point_at_your_stuff__All_the_above,_plus_link_your_data_to_other_people’s_data__to_provide_context_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS04.pdf LEC-LS04

 173  } DBpedia is a community effort to
§ extract structured (“infobox”) information from Wikipedia
§ provide a query endpoint to the dataset
§ interlink the DBpedia dataset with other datasets on the Web
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_173__} DBpedia_is_a_community_effort_to

} An RDF Triple (s,p,o) is such that:
§ “s”, “p” are URI-s, ie, resources on the Web; “o” is a URI or a literal
 “s”, “p”, and “o” stand for “subject”, “property”, and “object”
§ here is the complete triple:
} RDF is a general model for such triples (with machine readable formats like RDF/XML, Turtle, N3, RDFa, Json, …)
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/} An_RDF_Triple_(s,p,o)_is_such_that:
§ “s”,_“p”_are_URI-s,_ie,_resources_on_the_Web;_“o”_is_a_URI_or_a_literal
 “s”,_“p”,_and_“o”_stand_for_“subject”,_“property”,_and_“object”
§ here_is_the_complete_triple:
} RDF_is_a_general_model_for_such_triples_(with_machine_readable_formats_like_RDF/XML,_Turtle,_N3,_RDFa,_Json,_…)

specifying how to retrieve them, e.g., urn:isbn:0451450523 . http://dbpedia.org/resource/specifying_how_to_retrieve_them,_e.g.,_urn:isbn:0451450523_. courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS03.pdf LEC-LS03

(76)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(76)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS03.pdf LEC-LS03
 76  } The RDF Semantics document has a list of (33) entailment rules:
§ “if such and such triples are in the graph, add this and this”
§ do that recursively until the graph does not change
} The relevant rule for our example:
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_76__} The_RDF_Semantics_document_has_a_list_of_(33)_entailment_rules:
§ “if_such_and_such_triples_are_in_the_graph,_add_this_and_this”
§ do_that_recursively_until_the_graph_does_not_change
} The_relevant_rule_for_our_example:

 228  } Represent and share classiﬁcations, glossaries, thesauri, etc
§ for example:
• Dewey Decimal Classiﬁcation, Art and Architecture Thesaurus, ACM classiﬁcation of keywords and terms…
• classiﬁcation/formalization of Web 2.0 type tags
} Deﬁne classes and properties to add those structures to an RDF universe
§ allow for a quick port of this traditional data, combine it with other data
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_228__} Represent_and_share_classiﬁcations,_glossaries,_thesauri,_etc
§ for_example:
• Dewey_Decimal_Classiﬁcation,_Art_and_Architecture_Thesaurus,_ACM_classiﬁcation_of_keywords_and_terms…

 231  } The structure of the LOC page is fairly typical
§ label, alternate label, narrower, broader, …
§ there is even an ISO standard for these
} SKOS provides a basic structure to create an RDF representation of these
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_231__} The_structure_of_the_LOC_page_is_fairly_typical
§ label,_alternate_label,_narrower,_broader,_…

} SKOS_provides_a_basic_structure_to_create_an_RDF_representation_of_these

(64)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(64)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02
 64  } For example, using Python+RDFLib:
§ a “Graph” object is created
§ the RDF ﬁle is parsed and results stored in the Graph
§ the Graph offers methods to retrieve (or add):
• triples
• (property,object) pairs for a speciﬁc subject
• (subject,property) pairs for speciﬁc object
• etc.
§ the rest is conventional programming…
} Similar tools exist in Java, PHP , etc.
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_64__} For_example,_using_Python+RDFLib:
§ a_“Graph”_object_is_created
§ the_RDF_ﬁle_is_parsed_and_results_stored_in_the_Graph
§ the_Graph_offers_methods_to_retrieve_(or_add):
• triples
• (property,object)_pairs_for_a_speciﬁc_subject
• (subject,property)_pairs_for_speciﬁc_object
• etc.
§ the_rest_is_conventional_programming…
} Similar_tools_exist_in_Java,_PHP_,_etc.

 65   http://dbpedia.org/resource/_65__ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02
  # create a graph from a file   graph = rdflib.Graph()   graph.parse("filename.rdf", format="rdfxml")   # take subject with a known URI   subject = rdflib.URIRef("URI_of_Subject")   # process all properties and objects for this subject   for (s,p,o) in graph.triples((subject,None,None)) :     do_something(p,o)    René Witte http://dbpedia.org/resource/__#_create_a_graph_from_a_file___graph_=_rdflib.Graph()___graph.parse("filename.rdf",_format="rdfxml")___#_take_subject_with_a_known_URI___subject_=_rdflib.URIRef("URI_of_Subject")___#_process_all_properties_and_objects_for_this_subject___for_(s,p,o)_in_graph.triples((subject,None,None))_:_____do_something(p,o)____René_Witte courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02

(30)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(30)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02
 30  } User of data “F” can now ask queries like:
§ “give me the title of the original”
• well, … « donnes-moi le titre de l’original »
} This information is not in the dataset “F”…
} …but can be retrieved by merging with dataset “A”!
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_30__} User_of_data_“F”_can_now_ask_queries_like:
§ “give_me_the_title_of_the_original”
• well,_…_«_donnes-moi_le_titre_de_l’original_»
} This_information_is_not_in_the_dataset_“F”…
} …but_can_be_retrieved_by_merging_with_dataset_“A”!

(31)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(31)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02
 31  } We “feel” that a:author and f:auteur should be the same
} But an automatic merge doest not know that!
} Let us add some extra information to the merged data:
§ a:author same as f:auteur
§ both identify a “Person”
§ a term that a community may have already deﬁned:
• a “Person” is uniquely identiﬁed by his/her name and, say, homepage
• it can be used as a “category” for certain type of resources
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_31__} We_“feel”_that_a:author_and_f:auteur_should_be_the_same
} But_an_automatic_merge_doest_not_know_that!
} Let_us_add_some_extra_information_to_the_merged_data:
§ a:author_same_as_f:auteur
§ both_identify_a_“Person”
§ a_term_that_a_community_may_have_already_deﬁned:
• a_“Person”_is_uniquely_identiﬁed_by_his/her_name_and,_say,_homepage
• it_can_be_used_as_a_“category”_for_certain_type_of_resources

(33)  http://dbpedia.org/resource/(33)_ courses/COMP6741/LEC/LS02.pdf LEC-LS02
 33  } User of dataset “F” can now query:
§ “donnes-moi la page d’accueil de l’auteur de l’original”
• well… “give me the home page of the original’s ‘auteur’”
} The information is not in datasets “F” or “A”…
} …but was made available by:
§ merging datasets “A” and datasets “F”
§ adding three simple extra statements as an extra “glue”
 http://dbpedia.org/resource/_33__} User_of_dataset_“F”_can_now_query:
§ “donnes-moi_la_page_d’accueil_de_l’auteur_de_l’original”
• well…_“give_me_the_home_page_of_the_original’s_‘auteur’”
} The_information_is_not_in_datasets_“F”_or_“A”…
} …but_was_made_available_by:
§ merging_datasets_“A”_and_datasets_“F”
§ adding_three_simple_extra_statements_as_an_extra_“glue”

 34  } Using, e.g., the “Person”, the dataset can be combined with other sources
} For example, data in Wikipedia can be extracted using dedicated tools
§ e.g., the “dbpedia” project can extract the “infobox” information from Wikipedia already…
